title: The 10-2 Challenge
description: Got this note from a reader and been obsessing about it lately: â€œI just wrapped up a 10 â€“ 2 challenge. Hereâ€™s how it works... Read More [This post, The 10-2 Challenge, was first published by J. Money on Budgets Are Sexy]
author: J. Money
excerpt: An easy way to accomplish a goal - big or small: Spend 10 minutes a day on it, for 2 years! It equates to 7,300 mins or 122 hours!
text: Got this note from a reader and been obsessing about it lately: â€œI just wrapped up a 10 â€“ 2 challenge. Hereâ€™s how it works â€“ You work on a long term project for 10 minutes a day â€“ every day â€“ for approximately 2 years. The thing is, you have to work on the project every day. If you travel, you have to either improvise or do make up work for the days you missed. I even use a stopwatchÂ to make sure I work on the project for a full 10 minutes. Youâ€™ll be amazed at what you accomplish!â€ Love it! Super easy sounding, right?! And if I whip out a calculator here, hold on one secâ€¦Â  It looks like it actually adds up toâ€¦ 7,300 minutes!! Or roughly 122 hours! WOW! Imagine dedicating that many hours to *one* single goal of yours? What would you be able to achieve?! How better off would you be? Physically/mentally/professionally? Itâ€™s hard to fathom the number of things we let fall by the wayside just because theyâ€™re â€œtoo bigâ€ to start, so let this be the kick in the ass you need to actually GET GOING on a dream that you may be putting off. Or even just something annoying that really needs to get done but you know will take forever! Lolâ€¦ Literally stop reading this right now and get going if you already have it in your head â€“ I promise itâ€™ll be better than reading the rest of this post ğŸ˜‚ If nothing crosses your mind, let me throw out some ideas: Review your finances every day (expenses, credit cards, budget, net worth, subscriptions, insurance, credit score, credit report â€“ plenty of things you could keep tabs on and improve) Declutter your entire house (each drawer, closet, *gasp* garage!) Get a new job/promoted (research, apply, improve skills) Get a new girlfriend/boyfriend/friend (same examples as above ğŸ¤£) Write a book! (might feel choppy with only 10 mins applied, but youâ€™ll probably find youâ€™ll spend more time once youâ€™re â€œin the flowâ€) Start a passion project (blog, book, TikTok, coin collection!) Work out every day (go for a walk, go for a run!, lift some weights, do some yoga, play some basketball â€“ you only have to do it for 10 mins!) Work out your mind every day (meditate, read, crossword puzzles, jigsaw puzzles! (Remember that time I got obsessed with them for like two months??! Man I went bonkersâ€¦)) Study the bible (my friend who came up with this 10-2 idea did exactly this â€“ used his time for the past two years to devour the bible and create a â€œspiritual warfare database!â€) Weed/Garden/Landscape (after a month youâ€™ll probably just be *maintaining* from that point on!) Learn a new language (Spanish? French? HTML?) Learn something else entirely new! (Programming, Video Editing, Baking) The options are endlessâ€¦ And I donâ€™t care who you are, everyone can spare 10 mins a day towards something thatâ€™s important to them. The years are going to pass anyways, why not get something extra out of it with minimal effort?! I found the perfect book too yesterday for tracking it all: I scooped it up at Goodwill as a future gift to my sister (it was only $2.99!), but now Iâ€™m thinking I need to keep it for myself, lolâ€¦ But how perfect is this for tracking?! Each date has a small section to jot down quick notes, and theyâ€™re stacked on top of each other so every year going forward when you come back to the same date you can see the previous yearsâ€™ notes on it. Which hopefully will keep you motivated and inspired! Hereâ€™s an inside page so you can see exactly what Iâ€™m talking aboutâ€¦ And yes, I just wrote in it so itâ€™s officially mine ğŸ˜‚ So you can see thereâ€™s a section there for each of the 5 years, so over time youâ€™ll be able to reflect on the previous yearsâ€™ successes and notes and you donâ€™t have to keep getting a new journal :) In fact, you could even turn this into a 10-5 Challenge if you really wanted to! Hahaâ€¦ And I just found it on Amazon too in case you want one for yourself (currently $15): One Line A Day: A Five-Year Memory Book But really, you can use anything to track this â€“ whatâ€™s important is just that you do! Use a Notes app, staple some blank papers together, or use a good old fashion Google Doc, it doesnâ€™t matter â€“ just track it however is most natural to you. And as youâ€™ll see, Iâ€™ve already started this challenge :) Which for me is to do *one thing a day* for someone, or some place, that helps them. I had been trying to get to a WEEK in a row of helping someone each day â€“ and even pulled it off once (see the PS at the end!) â€“ but if I could accomplish it for 2 YEARS straight that would be amazing. And on Nov. 6th youâ€™ll see Day #1 was completed! I gave a microwave to my friend Debbie whose old one just broke down (it had been sitting in my basement for 5 years!), and then I called my mother â€œjust to check on herâ€ and not to ask for something which is usually the case ğŸ˜† And since I had extra room there at the end, I made a note that we had won our leagueâ€™s soccer championships (and I scored in it!), so that future me will be reminded of the feat a year from now. Now some days I already know Iâ€™ll have trouble finding someone to help, or maybe not even be IN THE MOOD to help!, so on â€œoffâ€ days Iâ€™ll carve out the 10 minutes to simply strengthen my *mindset* overall, whether by reading or brainstorming or even by meditating â€“ that way with each passing day Iâ€™m even more *conscious* about the mission. The more you practice doing something, the better you get at it right?! And we have 7,300 mins with this challenge so weâ€™re gonna get GOOD!! So yeah â€“ Iâ€™m pretty stoked about this, and hopefully you are too :) Spend a few minutes thinking it over today, and then tomorrow get right to it and start tracking it all. It doesnâ€™t matter if itâ€™s something big or small or somewhere in between â€“ just get crackinâ€™ and feel good about it! Remember â€“ the time is going to pass anyways, so why not get something out of it? And I want to hear all about it! PS: The one week I accomplished this! Day 1: helped serve a community dinner for our homeless friends Day 2: helped give out free food and veggies at our local food bank Day 3: gave a buddy of mine a haircut as he was low on funds, and also just really doesnâ€™t like going to barbers! (And if youâ€™re wondering, yes â€“ I gave him a mohawk!! I canâ€™t be trusted to cut anything else! ğŸ˜‚) Day 4: helped my church archive old documents in their archives room â€“ not only fascinating to hold and touch old artifacts, but to learn the overall process of *properly archiving* too! Day 5: helped a friend get a website off the ground and move her childhood dream further along Day 6: brainstormed marketing and fundraising ideas for a new garden opening up in our city Day 7: co-led an after church youth session â€“ the scariest of all as a) I donâ€™t know or fully understand the bible at all (!!), and b) pre-teen kids are so awkward and quiet and really donâ€™t like to talk, hahaâ€¦ Though I did find a secret weapon: snacks! It was a pretty fantastic week, but also exhaustingâ€¦ Iâ€™ll have to be careful of my energy levels and find ways to self-care throughout the next two years so I donâ€™t accidentally burn out. // Link to book is an Amazon affiliate link (Visited 783 times, 27 visits today) Get blog posts automatically emailed to you!
html:
Got this note from a reader and been obsessing about it lately:

â€œI just wrapped up a 10 â€“ 2 challenge. Hereâ€™s how it works â€“ You work on a long term project for 10 minutes a day â€“ every day â€“ for approximately 2 years. The thing is, you have to work on the project every day. If you travel, you have to either improvise or do make up work for the days you missed. I even use a stopwatchÂ to make sure I work on the project for a full 10 minutes. Youâ€™ll be amazed at what you accomplish!â€

Love it! Super easy sounding, right?!

And if I whip out a calculator here, hold on one secâ€¦Â  It looks like it actually adds up toâ€¦ 7,300 minutes!! Or roughly 122 hours! WOW! Imagine dedicating that many hours to *one* single goal of yours? What would you be able to achieve?! How better off would you be? Physically/mentally/professionally?

Itâ€™s hard to fathom the number of things we let fall by the wayside just because theyâ€™re â€œtoo bigâ€ to start, so let this be the kick in the ass you need to actually GET GOING on a dream that you may be putting off. Or even just something annoying that really needs to get done but you know will take forever! Lolâ€¦ Literally stop reading this right now and get going if you already have it in your head â€“ I promise itâ€™ll be better than reading the rest of this post ğŸ˜‚

If nothing crosses your mind, let me throw out some ideas:

  • Review your finances every day (expenses, credit cards, budget, net worth, subscriptions, insurance, credit score, credit report â€“ plenty of things you could keep tabs on and improve)
  • Declutter your entire house (each drawer, closet, *gasp* garage!)
  • Get a new job/promoted (research, apply, improve skills)
  • Get a new girlfriend/boyfriend/friend (same examples as above ğŸ¤£)
  • Write a book! (might feel choppy with only 10 mins applied, but youâ€™ll probably find youâ€™ll spend more time once youâ€™re â€œin the flowâ€)
  • Start a passion project (blog, book, TikTok, coin collection!)
  • Work out every day (go for a walk, go for a run!, lift some weights, do some yoga, play some basketball â€“ you only have to do it for 10 mins!)
  • Work out your mind every day (meditate, read, crossword puzzles, jigsaw puzzles! (Remember that time I got obsessed with them for like two months??! Man I went bonkersâ€¦))
  • Study the bible (my friend who came up with this 10-2 idea did exactly this â€“ used his time for the past two years to devour the bible and create a â€œspiritual warfare database!â€)
  • Weed/Garden/Landscape (after a month youâ€™ll probably just be *maintaining* from that point on!)
  • Learn a new language (Spanish? French? HTML?)
  • Learn something else entirely new! (Programming, Video Editing, Baking)

The options are endlessâ€¦

And I donâ€™t care who you are, everyone can spare 10 mins a day towards something thatâ€™s important to them. The years are going to pass anyways, why not get something extra out of it with minimal effort?!

I found the perfect book too yesterday for tracking it all:

I scooped it up at Goodwill as a future gift to my sister (it was only $2.99!), but now Iâ€™m thinking I need to keep it for myself, lolâ€¦

But how perfect is this for tracking?! Each date has a small section to jot down quick notes, and theyâ€™re stacked on top of each other so every year going forward when you come back to the same date you can see the previous yearsâ€™ notes on it. Which hopefully will keep you motivated and inspired!

Hereâ€™s an inside page so you can see exactly what Iâ€™m talking aboutâ€¦ And yes, I just wrote in it so itâ€™s officially mine ğŸ˜‚

So you can see thereâ€™s a section there for each of the 5 years, so over time youâ€™ll be able to reflect on the previous yearsâ€™ successes and notes and you donâ€™t have to keep getting a new journal :) In fact, you could even turn this into a 10-5 Challenge if you really wanted to! Hahaâ€¦ And I just found it on Amazon too in case you want one for yourself (currently $15):

One Line A Day: A Five-Year Memory Book

But really, you can use anything to track this â€“ whatâ€™s important is just that you do! Use a Notes app, staple some blank papers together, or use a good old fashion Google Doc, it doesnâ€™t matter â€“ just track it however is most natural to you.

And as youâ€™ll see, Iâ€™ve already started this challenge :) Which for me is to do *one thing a day* for someone, or some place, that helps them. I had been trying to get to a WEEK in a row of helping someone each day â€“ and even pulled it off once (see the PS at the end!) â€“ but if I could accomplish it for 2 YEARS straight that would be amazing.

And on Nov. 6th youâ€™ll see Day #1 was completed! I gave a microwave to my friend Debbie whose old one just broke down (it had been sitting in my basement for 5 years!), and then I called my mother â€œjust to check on herâ€ and not to ask for something which is usually the case ğŸ˜† And since I had extra room there at the end, I made a note that we had won our leagueâ€™s soccer championships (and I scored in it!), so that future me will be reminded of the feat a year from now.

Now some days I already know Iâ€™ll have trouble finding someone to help, or maybe not even be IN THE MOOD to help!, so on â€œoffâ€ days Iâ€™ll carve out the 10 minutes to simply strengthen my *mindset* overall, whether by reading or brainstorming or even by meditating â€“ that way with each passing day Iâ€™m even more *conscious* about the mission. The more you practice doing something, the better you get at it right?! And we have 7,300 mins with this challenge so weâ€™re gonna get GOOD!!

So yeah â€“ Iâ€™m pretty stoked about this, and hopefully you are too :) Spend a few minutes thinking it over today, and then tomorrow get right to it and start tracking it all. It doesnâ€™t matter if itâ€™s something big or small or somewhere in between â€“ just get crackinâ€™ and feel good about it!

Remember â€“ the time is going to pass anyways, so why not get something out of it? And I want to hear all about it!

PS: The one week I accomplished this!

  • Day 1: helped serve a community dinner for our homeless friends
  • Day 2: helped give out free food and veggies at our local food bank
  • Day 3: gave a buddy of mine a haircut as he was low on funds, and also just really doesnâ€™t like going to barbers! (And if youâ€™re wondering, yes â€“ I gave him a mohawk!! I canâ€™t be trusted to cut anything else! ğŸ˜‚)
  • Day 4: helped my church archive old documents in their archives room â€“ not only fascinating to hold and touch old artifacts, but to learn the overall process of *properly archiving* too!
  • Day 5: helped a friend get a website off the ground and move her childhood dream further along
  • Day 6: brainstormed marketing and fundraising ideas for a new garden opening up in our city
  • Day 7: co-led an after church youth session â€“ the scariest of all as a) I donâ€™t know or fully understand the bible at all (!!), and b) pre-teen kids are so awkward and quiet and really donâ€™t like to talk, hahaâ€¦ Though I did find a secret weapon: snacks!

It was a pretty fantastic week, but also exhaustingâ€¦ Iâ€™ll have to be careful of my energy levels and find ways to self-care throughout the next two years so I donâ€™t accidentally burn out.
